It's the 75th birthday of Anne Frank, who wrote the famous "Anne Frank's Diary", if she didn't die in the holocaust during the WWII. She, just like you and me, loved to capture the particular shots in her daily life. Yet, in her time when the Nazi's terror was all around, her diary was not an collection of fear and tear. Instead, her story builds a tunnel of time that protect you from the bombardment and horrible sence, and guides you to her beautiful world. She has once said, "Nobody need wait a single moment before starting to improve the world." Life is short. Hers was even shorter that her family was betrayed and killed in the Nazi concentration camp in Bergen-Belsen in March 1945 when she was 16. While in memory of Anne Frank, I hope her diary can give us inspiration on our diaries.

urlLink urlLink Stanley is my favorite hang-out place in Hong Kong. The beach, the old market and the coffee shops...are the best place for a lazy afternoon! During our HK trip in March, Rebecca and I revisited Stanley again. We walked around and passed an abandoned beach-side hut. This afternoon at 3:00pm when I was working, my supervisor in De Anza College called me asking me if I could go to help a woman who desperately needed a tutor for the exam tommorow. I said "yes" with no considering. After 3 years of tutoring economics in De Anza, I have regarded tutorial center is one of my house, and sort of an ideal working place. But now I can only work as a volunteer due to SJSU's prohibition. It sucks...it really sucks...it makes me detest SJSU more...! It make a free-market advocate to hate any kind of unreasonable regulation!! On the other hand, however,it show how much I enjoy teaching. Using economic term, the marginal revenue of teaching is higher than the marginal cost. In other words, for a particular hour, I am free to choose working in Scott Cao Violin or De Anza, the former get paid while the latter does not. In money term, it doesn't make sense to give up the opportunity of earning and work for no paid. Yet, it is about economics. Economic does not really deal with money. Money is not the carrot that lures the donkey move forward. Instead, it is the utility, or happiness, behind the choice leading you make decision. Likewise, from a Christian point of view we go to church, or we help and love others are not for money(most of the time we sacrifice money), but by doing so we receive more revenue, in term of God's blessing, grace and peace. Therefore in general, most of the economists and Christians are rich, but they are all wealthy inside.

In the past few days, Rebecca and I have watched two magnificent movies – “Big Fish” and “The Whale Rider”. Both of them are two-thumb-up movies. “Big Fish” is a fanciful one that depicts the father-and-son relationship. The father made himself a heroic figure by telling the son many mystical bedside stories. Yet, when the son grew up, the story and the father’s heroic figure became treacherous. While the real image of the father from the son’s eyes is ambiguous, the gap between them is widened too. It was a father-day week; this movie drove me to ruminate over the relationship between my father and me. For more than 20 years, the relationship is intertwining with love and hatred, admiration and abomination. We know we always love each other, but we don’t really know each other. He was a great mathematic teacher with no doubt, I witnessed how he tutored his students at our home after school, and this has been proved by many of his students I met, in China, the U.S, and even in Germany. For many years in their heart, my father is always a great teacher who changed their life. Even so, he is the one who ruined my interest in maths. I have thought one day I will like him to be very good at mathes. But at that time, what can you expect from an elementary kid like me to learn advanced calculus and trigonometry? When I asked him a question, what I need was just simply the answer or a hint. I didn’t expect an even abstract lesson with many clumsy equations and proofs. Gradually I stopped asking him question, and my hay-day of maths no longer exists too. In many aspects, my father is a good husband and a good father – he cooks great food, he is good at calligraphy, he helps my mom, he does the laundry, he cleans up after dinner, and he usually not allow us to clean the dishes. What can I ask for more?! Well, these are all hardware, what I need is good software. I have once said that “I will never be the kind of man like my father.” I have confessed. God gives me the heart of forgiving and loving. I want to tell my father, “I love you!”

Pastor Alan and I went fishing yesterday early morning in Santa Cruz. It is an exceptional year that the Salmon season prolongs, so we joined a group of 20 people in a fishing boat and fished in Santa Cruz and Monteray Bay. Well...I have been exhausted from Church Sport day the day before but I didn't sleep well due to nerveousness. The boat departed sharply at 6:00am. The cloudiness and calmness of the sea made the sea more mysterious to me, and everybody on the boat looked solemn and serious, waiting for a big fish when the boat brought them to the right spot. Fishing in the sea is quite different from that in the lake or in the creek, as you are quite likely to throw up during that 8 hours in trouble wave. Althouht I had the anti-vomit pill, I did throw up. The first time in many years. Yet, after many hours fighting against the wind and wave, we didn't catch anything. Looking at those people who got Salmon (only 10 caught, the smallest one is over 25lbs), we were just so jealous and daunting. And all my Salmon recipe was varnished.... You know, I should have had a picture of me holding a big fish posted at here.....next time la....
